My dish was amazing. Thoroughly enjoyed myself - would definitely return.

Before last night this was one of our neighborhood choices.  We have been many time over the years.  Last night I was completely turned off to this restaurant.  We were a party of 5 and we were not happy with our table.  We asked if we could move to an empty table next to ours.  The waitress had to ask the hostess who said no because that table was reserved.  I asked if the other party could just take our table.  She had to ask the manager, who also said no.  I asked why and he said he needed to check.  By the time he came back and said we could move I was totally annoyed and just stayed at the table we didn't like or want since by now it was 15 minutes after they seated us.  What happened to the customer service at this restaurant?  In the end, the table we asked for sat empty for most of the time we were there.  About 20 minutes before we left they sat two people there.

Came here for restaurant week dinner.  The food is pretty good and the free bread excellent.  However, the restaurant week portion were embarrassingly small.  I had the bass and it wasn't even one fillet, but just a 2 inch end piece which was 3 bites.  I've had appetizers bigger than that.  They even skimped out on the dessert which was super disappointing.  I understand it's restaurant week and the price is only $38 but the amount of food we got wasn't even worth that amount.

We weren't even that hungry when we went to Casa Nonna. Still finished every bite on my plate (and a couple of bites on my friend's plate). Is there anything better than eating great Italian food in NYC? Is there any city in America better than NYC when it comes to great Italian food. Both rhetorical questions I know...The ambiance of this place is like updated, old-school (I know, I know)... It's nice and dark but has little touches of modernity all over it. I actually really liked the grand feel of this restaurant and, because of this, the cacophony of the boisterous group of Italians sitting next to us was only slightly annoying.The highlight was of course the food. Beautiful (just plain swell) pasta dishes that I seriously could have eaten a lot more of (despite my fullness) stole the proverbial show.There are so many excellent Italian restaurants I cant say that this will be our go-to spot. But it's surely a contender- especially if you're already in the area.

Went here for a restaurant week lunch. I have to say, I was very impressed! The options for the first course were gazpacho or salad, we tried salad, it was delicious. The second was salmon or spaghetti pomodoro, my husband and I ordered one of each and shared, both delicious again. For dessert, I got limoncello, he got tiramisu. Limoncello was too sweet and too sour to my taste, I would go with tiramisu next time. But the fast service, the ambiance and the whole experience was very pleasant! We will be back for sure!

Went there with my mom and brother and my 2 nieces.  They could not have been better to us.  We got in early and they sat us anyway.  Great table in back where it was quiet so grandma can talk to her grandkids.I forgot what we all had but I know we all loved it.  I know I split lobster salad with mom and she loved it.  Great job and great memories for my mom and nieces.  We don't get to see them allot so great to have a great dinner.Thank you to staff

Here's the deal:  I was definitely surprised by this place   The inside decor is very nice.   It offers a nice bar area and an open view of the pizza oven!    I've been here 2 times.  They offer yummy foccecia bread to start!   I've had a polo panini & and one of their personal pizza.   Both were very good   They offer homemade pasta dishes ( which I only tasted) it was very good!

I enjoyed the meal. Nice to see an "all Italian" theme. The Octopus appetizer was very good and the seasonal Vegetable Ragu was exceptional! The wine list was nice and conservatively priced. The service was a little disjointed but the team was courteous and prompt as they could be. I will be back.

Service sucks waiting for almost 25 minutes for my food. A party of 10 came in and are settled and there food is on the table. Guess my money ant green. Just got my food had a 8:30 reservation it's 9:10.

Really wanted to like this place. Had a family dinner here and was seated in no time. I ordered the squid ink pasta dish w/ bay scallops which was good. Someone else in my group got the Frute De Mare (however you spell it) and it was good except the mussels were overcooked and tough. The last person in our group got the chicken parm. When that arrived it was a huge piece of chicken. However, upon cutting into it, we saw that it was very undercooked (the meat was clear and tough) so we sent it back, no problem. I get that it happens every once in awhile so we didn't make a fuss about it. The manager even came over and apologized for the dish. They brought out a fresh new piece of chicken (also huge portion), and we discovered this one was even more undercooked than the first one. The meat was pinkish/clear and was absolutely 100% undercooked - no doubt about it. So we got the waitress again and told her it was undercooked...again. She (and another waiter) both confirmed it was undercooked when they were at the table. So they took it back and we said that we didn't want another one, just give us the dessert menu. The manager came out again, and had the audacity to tell us that she looked at it in the kitchen and it was cooked perfectly fine. I get that it wasn't her fault, it was the cook's fault, and it happens sometimes, whatever. But to come to my table and lie straight to my face is absurd. I would have given this place a 1 star, but they didn't charge us for the two chickens that were undercooked, and they gave us all free dessert (which was mediocre). All in all, i will never eat here again. Stay away, or at least don't order the chicken parm.

Possibly the best agnolotti I have had in a while! I went for risotto but they didn't have it but I had the veal and spinach agnolotti and it was superb! The cream, the mushrooms and the creaminess of both veal and spinach! Personally, I found the place quite charming.I went for lunch, sat in a corner, and it was serene regardless of the fact that it was packed! I recommend it to anyone who wants good italian food.The service as well was great, really sweet and helpful staff!

Been here many times over the past few years, and casa nonna has never disappointed.  Delicious food in an otherwise average/crowded area.  I have dreams about the flatbread they serve before the meal - so incredibly good.  Some of my favorite items include gnocchi, pici alla toscana (beef-pork ragu- a bit salty but incredible flavor), and the calamari especially is to die for.  A bit expensive, but the food and the amibence make up for it.

Second time to eat here & have enjoyed it both times. Reservation made seating a snap, good happy hour specials in the bar ($6 blood orange margarita was my choice). Service is prompt & attentive, the tender, crispy, buttery, herb-y grilled flatbread served at the table is heavenly, & the menu enticing. They kindly split the caprese salad for myself & a colleague. It's a must - heirloom tomatoes, the freshest mozzarella, tender basil leaves & a delicious balsamic dressing. Another colleague had the chilled tomato & basil soup which he liked as well. I had the Siamese agnolotti which was tender & delicious. It's a gem in an area without many - accessible to penn station, the garden, javits. I'll certainly be back!

This restaurant is a glorified TGIF. Full of tourists and service was shotty.  Had to track down the waitress every time we needed something. Very very over priced. I have spent the same if not less at Zagat 3. Star rated restaurants.

Over priced for what it offers. This was my 2nd visit, the first time with a group of 12 and this time solo. While nothing was wrong with the meals, it just in my opinion is overpriced for what was delivered. I eat out often, and with some work, one can find better food at better prices. The pasta dish I had was bland, the siamese agnolotti. Suggested as one of the best pasta dishes on the menu, it simply missed the mark.The service was attentive and informative, both for our large group and sitting solo at the bar.

We enjoyed our lunch very much...authentic Italian! The food was delicious, the champagne was chilled and the staff was very attentive and polite. My wife and I celebrated our marriage along with 10 family members here and it did not disappoint! We will definitely be back. Thanks for everything!

Came here on a Saturday afternoon after watching a Broadway play. Most restaurants in the theater district were booked, but this was one was open and the menu looked good so we gave it a shot.I'm very happy we did. This restaurant is enormous. Very nice and classy ambience. They have private rooms, a bar, tables, and what looks to be like a "pizza bar". It has a counter with seats where they make pizza by wood burning ovens. Our party had chicken parm, a seafood pasta, and one of their pizzas. All was amazing. No complaints whatsoever. Dessert was very good as well.Our server was extremely friendly and attentive. Checking in with us at all times to make sure we had everything we wanted. My friend had a raspberry lemonade and when our server asked her if she liked it she told him it was a bit sweet and he with no hesitation said he would take it off the bill. We weren't even looking for that, but what a plus.As far as price, it's mid-level. What you would expect in the city. Maybe even below average a bit.If you like Italian- just go here.

Thank you fellow Yelpers... when our first choice for Italian in the neighborhood was overcrowded you steered me here to Nonna. This is a great find. It is a strange thing for a New York restaurant... it is spacious! A large airy space with plenty of room between the tables. The menu is great. I would love to come back and try their regional Italian prix fixe option. I had the special heirloom tomato salad w/ buffala mozzarella... perfect. My main was the Pappardelle Porci... spot on... real "homemade" flavor. The best thing is how reasonable the prices are considering the quality and the upscale setting. I have one knock... our waiter was terrible. He apologized at one point and said he was new. I accept his apology. He was a nice guy... just slow. I wouldn't let this hiccup stop me from coming back!

Came here with a friend for dinner on a Thursday night and had a great time! The restaurant is huge and has lots of tables. Our server was also really nice and attentive! We ordered:Entree:*Pappardelle Al Porcini - porcini pasta, braised boar ragu, mushrooms, dried cranberries. The pasta is all made in house (you can see them as you walk in), the portion was large, and the dish was overall very delicious!*Pesce Spada - grilled swordfish, roasted peppers, tomato, black olives, capers. The swordfish serving is pretty small portion but my friend liked it!Wine/dessert:*Wine: a wine from Barbaresco - I wish I remembered which one because it was so good!*Dessert: Seasonal fruit plateOur dinner took about 3 hours because everything was so delicious, the environment was great, and also because our server left towards the end and the other server never came to our table to give us the bill even though we were almost the only people left at the restaurant...besides that, the dinner was pretty much perfect so would recommend for groups who love Italian, romantic dates, or even friends catching up!

I work in midtown which is basically sports/irish bar central so this was a great find! When you want to have a quick date night close to Penn Station your options are a little limited. We have gone here twice now and on both occasions had a great experience. Great wine selection, and the BF had his favorite chicken parm and was a fan. I had a seafood pasta the first time and gnocchi the second. The gnocchi were a little bit overcooked and mushy but the sauce more than made up for that as I would have gladly taken a plate of sauce (with I believe ground lamb) without any pasta! Servers on both occasions nice. The second time though a little disappointed that they did not come back after the meal was served because I really wanted more wine. By the time she came back I was almost done...but still took a second glass :) Overall if you are in the area worth a try!

Horrible service. Food is not great for the price. Waiter was more interested in socializing with other waiter rather than filling our water. Did not give us menus or kids menu. Rude wait staff. Go somewhere else..food and service are horrible here!

So it's not cheap per se, and some may say the service is lacking (although it was fine when I went) but the food is excellent. There's no arguing that. Well executed classics without being ironic or retro. I especially loved the bruschetta appetizer.

What's not to like?! We went on a Saturday night. The place is large for a New York restaurant, but cozy. It is a little darker in there, but it makes for a more relaxing atmosphere. The decor was nice. The food was outstanding. All five us of loved our meals. Homemade pasta, some creative dishes, lots of flavor. The staff was great- they checked up on us and made sure we had everything we wanted. Our water glasses were always full. I'll definitely return.

Atmosphere is fairly dark, which makes it seem quieter despite the noise of the patrons. I sat on a bar stool which overlooked the kitchen and could see them methodically preparing the food.I ordered the chicken parmegana, which was quite possibly the best one I've ever eaten. The cheese atop is plentiful and actually sticks to the chicken when you cut it, unlike most other chicken parms I've had. The pasta with it comes with greens infused in the pasta itself. It was pleasant - makes you feel like you're getting your vegetables and helps justify the 1000+ calories from the meal. Fast service and you even get a complimentary little dessert at the end.

My friend and I loved the restaurant and the editor... But the next day we were both sick in bed from the food.  that meatball! And unfortunately the restaurant was also overpriced for something simple like spaghetti and a meatball was $24... But I guess that's midtown for people.

I came here on Monday, December 30th at around 9:30pm, and although we had a reservation, we went right to the bar.First, let me tell you how pretty this place is.  Definitely love the ambiance and the front bar area.Then we had the pleasure of meeting JUSTIN ARAUJO.  Let me tell you, every manager should take a lesson from this guy.  Both my guest and myself have been i the restaurant industry our whole entire lives, and managers like this are what we live for.  Not only was he so well put together, but was so conversational without being intrusive.  He made our experience amazing.The food was awesome, (and the bottles of wine were 1/2 price...whatttt???)  but THE main reason I will come back is because of The Manger Justin.  He made our night.There was also a blonde bartender, tall and also extremely nice!  Everything a bartender should be;  witty and conversational, but non-intrusive.Good Job Casa Nonna, and thank you to Justin again!
Good lord that was a lot of good food. Work out required post meal but it will be worth every mile. :-)

This place is amazing. The atmosphere is very quiet and comforting. The service was a little slow that's why I am giving it four stars. The food deserves five stars. I ate about four pieces of the cheesy bread. Hands down best gnocchi I have ever had. It came with a lamb sausage red sauce which was sinful. I also tried the tortellini which was amazing. The tortellini are huge though. I also had the chicken Parmesan (huge also) and it was super. For dessert we had this peach tart and I went to heaven.  If I am in the area I will definitely come back here to order the steak.

Excellent all around! Found this restaurant on Google maps while looking for a place to eat near the theater district. We wanted something that was fancy but not overly expensive and that also could accommodate speciality diets. Casa Nonna was the perfect choice! We had a 5pm reservation on Sunday evening and were seated right away. The restaurant wasn't crowded yet so the atmosphere was quiet and relaxed. The staff was attentive and happy. I had already been given a list of food that was already or could be made vegan which was great. But I also checked with our server again just to be sure and she was well informed on what options I had and made sure the kitchen knew I was vegan. The food was standout and will not hesitate going back the next time I'm in NYC!
Went for lunch with mother great service food excellent an good price for the area. Dessert I loved

FabulousThis place is terrific. It's quite large but feels intimate. The food is outstanding , I especially enjoyed the crazy bruschetta and the black bow tie pasta with seafood and sea urchin "carbonara." The butter squash ravioli was to die for. For mid town just off the theater district it's not that pricey. The service is impeccable, it's not touristy, it's classy without being pretentious, I highly recommend this spot.

Not bad.Delicious focaccia for a bread basket.The chicken parm was good but there was too much basil and it was served lukewarm.  The crispy potatoes and garlic aioli on the side were really good.I wish they would utilize that wood fired oven a bit more with their entree options.The service was a bit lacking too.

Warm, quiet ambiance, great for dinner with friends or eating while reading.  Charming decor, like a grandma's sitting room.  FOOD: Cheesy flat bread - out of control good.  Polpattine with ricatta - super yummy.  Fried calamari - OK.  Nicely seasoned, heavily fried, vegetables wound up being soggy.  Ribeye - overcooked but delicious.  Papperdelle al porcine - Toothy pasta, very hearty, underseasoned.  Cranberries were meant to brighten it up but didn't quite get the job done.  Torta di Cioccolato - decadent.  Strong flavor of coffee which was not described in the menu but suited me just fine.  Gelato - very good.SERVICE: Expect to eat at a relaxed pace.  Not necessarily the place to grab and go, but a lovely location for a long evening meal.Overall I would go again!Paul White

Pretty good experience for Restaurant Week.The RW menu is made of the items you'd find on their regular menuThe lighting it awesome and makes the place feel dark and cozyThe service was professional and amount of time it took food to come was faster than average.The complimentary Grilled Focacciaa Bread was awesome.Warm,crispy, flaky and straight from the oven. The waiter said they are made to order.The Cipolotta (Onion soup) was pretty good and came with two pieces of delicious cheese topped Italian bread slices. Portion size looked pretty much what you'd expect ordering off the regular menu too.The Bistecca Flanco (Flank Steak) entree was delicious. The size was a little small, about 5z, but perfectly cooked with a nice charred flavor. The garlic cauliflower  puree was so good.The Torta di Polenta dessert was disappointing. You ever have those little poopyseed muffins from the store that come in a box? Identical. Get the Tiramisu instead.
I hosted a business lunch here. 7 people, they accommodated us very well, the food was excellent, and so was the service. I will definitely be back!

Came here for Restaurant Week. A Lil wary of that concept cause last year elsewhere was a bust. NOT THIS TIME!!! what a splendid and comfy cove!! The menu was just right, had a great variety of Italian treats and specials. The drinks were simply divine and tasty. FRIENDLY ADVISE: if u get the nonna pick up drink, have it with dessert, it's so chocolatey  good!!
Went in for lunch restaurant week. Menu was good. Small portions but left satisfied. Dessert lemon poppy polenta cake was amazing. Service could of been alot better and more attentive but overall ok.

I went last night for Valentines day and had an absolutely amazing meal with great service. Our waiter Stefan made great recommendations and was very knowledgeable about the menu and wine list. He made our experience really excellent. We ordered the burratta that was made in house and was absolutely delicious. We also ordered the filet and duo-ravioli. The filet was huge and cooked perfectly. The duo-ravioli was made with a lamb ragu and a spinach and ricotta mix and was AMAZING! We will be back again soon

Booked on open table (disappointed the hostess didn't check us in, so I had to straighten that out with Open Table so I wasn't a "no-show"). My boyfriend and I were trying to catch an 8pm play, and we wanted to get dinner beforehand. We booked here and were pleasantly surprised. Atmosphere is warm but very open. The staff was friendly. Cocktails were DELICIOUS. Their home made bread was delicious and well seasoned, a little over-oiled though. We started with calamari, which was yummy! Served with a tartar sauce, not marinara, very tart and delicious. I got spaghetti pomodoro, which was fresh and the pasta was home made. The tomato sauce was fresh and had wonderful chunks of tomatoes. My boyfriend got swordfish which was cooked to perfection. It was delicious. Overall, we were very happy with our meal and I'd go back.

My wife and I went to Casa Nonna based on a recommendation by our hotel concierge.  We have been to many Italian places throughout the years, however this was a cut above the rest.  Quite possibly might have been the best meal we ever had.We got the Polpettine (meatballs), Spaghetti Pomodoro, and Patate Croccante (potato wedges).  When the food comes out, it is brought out and they explain to you exactly what it is, mostly in Italian and very fast!  My wife speaks some Italian and understood most of it but it was an experience to have it explained like that.  The meatballs were easily the best I have ever had. They came with fresh ricotta cheese, and melted in your mouth as you ate them.  The spaghetti was cooked PERFECTLY and the sauce was delicious.  It also came formed into a mound (the waiter explained that they use a metal collar to form it and then remove the collar before serving).  The potato wedges were also delicious, cooked perfectly, seasoned with garlic, olive oil, and rosemary.For dessert we chose to go with the Torta di Cioccolato.  It was light and airy mousse, on a bed of devil's food cake, served with some fantastic amaretto gelato with crumbs in it to make it crunchy.  Perfect way to finish off the meal.Casa Nonna is truly a wonderful experience and we will certainly be back next time we are in NYC!
Solid happy hour spot. $6 wine and FREE food? where lse can you get such an amazing deal? Check out the Montepulciano red wine. such an amazing drink for only $6 is a steal!
The food and service was wonderful.   Always attentive.   Delicious game hen and the ricotta cheese cake was divine.
Great experience until I saw them tuned to Al Jazeera on bar TV

This is one of the best Italian food restaurants I have been too. The ambiance is cozy and what makes them different is they have round booths which are so comfortable to sit on. Compared to the traditional chairs , the booth makes it even perfect for a large group! My husband and I really enjoyed the food, service was great, our server was very friendly kept smiling and even bought us extra rosemary bread on request. Overall great place you must try !!

I love this spot. Great tasting food. Lobster salad was great light nd refreshing, as well as the beet salad with the arugula. Li have nothing but good things to say about their tasty food. Dessert was excellent as well. ( My favorite part )

You walk in and don't expect it to be so large! The ambiance is casual and friendly. The filet mignon was INCREDIBLE. So was the butternut squash ravioli. The bread you get while you wait is different but so tasty. It's decently priced and would make a good first date spot. Get dessert too!!!

Great place, cozy, great ambiance, really good food as fast service. I have been a fan of Casa Nonna for quite some time and my last visit reminded me why. Food: The saltimbocca alla romana wras eally good, although I found the kale side to be a lot more memorable. The pan seared scallops are also a great choice and the capesante panini is the best. For dessert, the panna cotta is certainly the way to go.I like the décor a lot, low lights, woodened furniture with an unpretentious modern touch to it. Ample space at and in between the table, great and fast service. I highly recommend for groups.

AMAZING! Great location and ambiance. Perfect for a date night or client dinner. The bread they bring to your table will change your life. It's absolutely delicious. For appetizers we ordered both the CALAMARI FRITTI and the POLPETTINE and both were ridiculously good. Seriously. For entrees we opted to split the POLLO ALLA PARMIGIANA and the PICI ALLA TOSCANA and both were equally wonderful. Highly recommended! Can't wait to come back.

Wow. Thank you help. We were around the corner at Tir NA nog but my guess didn't want pub food. We saw this place and went around the block. Awesome salads. Veal and chicken dishes fabulous. 1/2 off on wine list. Casandra our waitress was soo professional and helpful. Can't wait to come back.

We came here for our New Year's Eve dinner and we had a great experience. We had the Octopus and the Polenta for starters, and they were both excellent. Our entrees were also great. The highlight was the superbly cooked Venison that they had in their special NYE menu but I ordered a la carte. The deserts were also very good. Only minor complaint is that the wine menu (exclusively Italian wines) was a bit overpriced and not so great.

STAY AWAY!. This fake Italian restaurant has poor service and worse food. I gave this place a second chance last week and it was a worse experience than the first. We had to ask three times for bread, the meal took 40 minutes to serve, Stouffers in a microwave is far more tasty than what they serve. So overpriced for the poor quality menu, it's ridiculous.

Came to Casa Nonna for a rehearsal dinner and fell in love with the restaurant.  The atmosphere was lovely in that we had our own section of the restaurant just for us.  They have a really great Caesar salad, which is hard to come by.  Their cheese ravioli safe to die for and they're chocolate lava cake is divine!   I would highly recommend this restaurant.

Crowded bar area on a Friday after work.  Super busy bartenders doing their best because this restaurant is huge and they made all the drinks and poured all the wine for it.  Calamari was NOT good.  Really greasy and over cooked.  The true sign of a quality Italian restaurant is their calamari, imho. Pretty restaurant atmosphere.  Jazz in the background. Clean restroom which is a mile from the bar.   A little expensive. We MAY try again, may not.

From the outside the restaurant  caught my eye. Very pretty and elegant atmosphere and big which is good so you don't feel on top of people. My friends and I decided to go there to eat on a Friday night.  Wait time was 30 min even though she told us less and there was tables open.  The food was very good and fresh. I had truffle gnocchi which was perfectly cooked and so tasty the pasta portions were great to full you up. Its on the pricey side, but it was worth a try! Hope to make another visit

My Fiance and I had no idea what all the fancy Italian titles meant, but the staff was so helpful and friendly about suggesting dishes. The entire meal was incredible, and rang up to be much less than I would have anticipated. I would absolutely recommend to anyone looking for a romantic night out with great service.

The food was decent but they were out of half the menu - including specialty cocktails. When the food was brought to the table only some of us were served and by the time the rest of the food was brought out 10 minutes had passed and our food was cold. Also our server literally disappeared and another server had to finish our experience. The original server never came back. The server that picked up the pieces did a great job trying to salvage our experience. Maybe this was a complete once off but with so much competition in NYC, a restaurant's bar, front of the house and back of the house can't all be down at the same time. It is obviously a poorly managed restaurant.

Party of 10 on a Saturday night.  Place was nice, service was good and the food was good.  But, the restaurant was overpriced especially relative to the portion size.  Several of the group ordered scallops and got 3 scallops and a very small vegetable for about $30.  Finished the meal and still hungry.  Not at those prices.

Had a great lunch here. Very comfortable, good staff, and good food. Not the cheapest by a long shot, but the ingredients were high quality and fresh. I had a pasta and veggie dish that was very well done. I usually hate paying $21 for a pasta dish, but this was almost worth it. :-) we also had some of their pizza which was good, too. A great place to rest from the NYC fray for a bit. I would hit it again if I wanted to make sure I was getting good food and wasn't worried too much about price.

Full gluten free menu with pasta dishes.  Had the frutti di mare,  gluten free pasta was cooked to perfection,  it had squid,  Shrimp,  clams and mussels.  In beer they have docs draft hard apple cider,  it's gluten free.

I arranged a company dinner at Casa Nonna in their private room and it was nothing short of perfect. The event planner there, Rachel, was super professional and helpful. The staff (Elliott, Jonah, and Lindsay) was incredibly helpful and kind. They had a TV so we were able to do presentations to our group. Waiters even helped with technical issues, which I'm sure is not part of their job descriptions. They have a massive wine menu and we chose two different ones that I loved. We had a preset menu that included: Primi - Tre Formaggi TortelliniSecondi - Agnello Alla Griglia (lamb) and Pesce Spada (swordfish)Sides - Broccoli Rabe and Roasted PotatoesDessert - Chocolate Lava Cake with Vanilla Ice Cream and Panna Cotta Everything was delicious. I could rave all night about the chocolate cake and ice cream. Can't wait until my company decides to have another dinner here!

I entered, soaked in rain, and cold. You handed me a glass of red wine and ricotta bruschetta...  The ricotta were soft fluffy clouds in my mouth that buffeted me above the rain storm, to a warm and happy place... I was getting happier and happier...  But then a bolt of lightning hit, the waitress ignored our table, forgot requests for water, sent the wrong order, dinner arrived 40 mins after ordering... And we quickly tumbled from 5 to 3 stars. I'll probably go back once more, with the hopes that that was just an off night... Till then I'll dream sweet dreams of their ricotta bruschetta....

This was a wonderful finish for our visit.  The food was amazing and the service was great.  We had the filet, the short ribs, and the Branzino.  Each dish was exceptional.  Our server did a great job but Lindsay, one of the managers, made dinner a delight.  Definitely a great place for a celebration or romantic dinner.
We love to stop here when we come into town for an event at MSG. Great service, awesome food.

What an amazing dinner!!! Great service and phenomenal Italian dishes! Highly recommend the polpi salad...I've had octopus salad at many different places, but none quite like this...outstanding! And followed w/the agnolotti...PERFECT.  I will be back...thank you for a wonderful surprise...stumbled upon your happy restaurant and so thankful for it!

We were here on a Monday evening at the suggestion of our hotel concierge. We were delighted to find all bottles of wine to be half price on Monday evening, and I guess this accounted for the level of busy they were experiencing! All the staff were pleasant and helpful, especially Nick who helped us select wine and answered my random food questions. We had calamari to start which was delicious, not chewy and lightly battered. It was a huge portion though, so we were glad we shared. We both had pizza one Parma and one Bosco. They took quite a while to arrive, but as we were enjoying a nice La Vigne Cabernet and people watching this wasn't a big problem for us. The kitchen is semi open and the pizza oven has a bar alongside with seats so you can watch the activities. On the first night of a six week stay in NYC I'm glad we found this early on and we will definitely be back to try the home made pastas.

I was very disappointed in this restaurant after reading the reviews and scoping out the bar during lunch. It took 40 minutes at the table before flat bread (2 small triangles each) was served and another 30 minutes before our dinner made it to the table on a Monday night after what looked to be the busy hour. The wine was good and I could have overlooked the leisurely service had the meals been superb. Sadly, they were average (or less) at best. The lamb chops were exceptionally small, bland - hard to do with lamb - and overpriced. The marinara was pure tomato soup and meatballs were average. Next time I would stay at the bar and order appetizers.
Great place for dinner. Comfortable, great service, really good food, reasonably priced. I was pleasantly surprised to find this gem so close to our hotel in kind of a quiet area of NY.

Love this little oasis in the culinary desert that is the fashion district. I've only been there at happy hour. I had a scotch (which included a tasty little appetizer plate) and a pizza. All were delicious. Bartender was pleasant, ambiance was lovely. I will definitely be back. Hint: Join the rewards program for extra love from Casa Nonna.

I wanted a GOOD dinner on out lady night in NYC. Not too pricey, but no more fast food! Yelp delivered and led me here.... food was delish, and the drinks were on point. A good Italian spot always knows hours to pour a good negrini :) This is a great sorry for a nice dinner with friends or a date with that special someone :)

I ate dinner there with my daughter and her boyfriend. The bar area is nice and lively suitable for dining- suitable for walking from Penn station(not super close but walkable).The restaurant was nice and the service was great. I plan to go back there again when in NYC-budget minded beware...the place is not cheap...

My wife and I visited this restaurant on a Monday night in August and were very excited to have an Italian Restaurant one block away from our hotel. My wife loved her dinner which was the Swordfish. I on the other hand was very disappointed as I ordered the Veal Saltimbucca and it came not anywhere near what I was used to. I had like 4 slices of veal that were tough not sauced at all. The waitress who was horrible asked if me about my dish and I told her and she basically was oh well sorry. You'd think maybe an offer of a drink or something but she just walked away and hardly came around to the table. I probably would not visit again.

I've debated for 2 weeks whether or not to post a review for this restaurant on account of the fact that I went for restaurant week lunch rather than ordering from the regular menu.  After much consideration, I've decided that if a restaurant is going to offer a set menu, the food should at least be edible.  The fish, skate, simply was not.  It had the sickening stench of ammonia and ruined my appetite for the day after the first bite.  I hope that this can be attributed to bad luck as opposed to the restaurant trying to pass off bad food. Moreover, the service was haphazard.  For instance, at least three servers inquired as to whether we wanted bread (which when it arived 20 mins later was very good).  Our failure to order alcoholic drinks, at lunch midweek, was met with a sneer. The starter, watermelon salad, and dessert, were each good but not exceptional in a city with countless hihg-end Italian retaurants.  Service from start to finish was near two hours which working people simply cannot deal with after expressly informing the staff of our concern.  Six people with tax and tip was approximately $200+ with tax and tip off the set menu.  For that amount of money I feel as though we could have gone to a nice restaurant without a restaurant week menu and had a better experience.
Service and location is good but it s too expensive.Food is ok and the dishes are not so big.Try the pizza with the truffle oil, is good.

Casa Nonna was great! The staff is so friendly and attentive ! The food was also unexpectedly good .. We had the burrata n lobster salad which was very tasty and lite... The steak tar tar which is one of the best I've had , octopus salad which was slightly warm n perfect cooked ... We then had 2 pasta dishes both amazing n a side of quinoa .. We finished off with 3 desserts ! The ricotta cheesecake the chocolate cake and the prosecco granita ! Everything was great!!

I came here with some family for a restaurant week dinner.  Overall we found the food and ambience to be really great. For dinner I had the pork belly appetizer which came with a light and delicious salad. It was a perfect amount of salty and fresh. I would say this was the best course of the meal. For the entree I had the fish with some kind of olive spread with artichokes and tomatoes.  The fish was a little dry but overall was a well seasoned. For dessert I had the frozen prosecco choice which looked a lot like a fruit cocktail upon delivery. It was a little sweet for me but I enjoyed the frozen watermelon and ices. I would definitely return to Casa Nonna as it was quite inviting and had quality food.
The food is light and delicate. Nice environment.Waiting is a little long, but service is good.

Came here for Restaurant Week lunch. The build out is very nice and the staff were very professional. However, the service was extremely slow. Normally people do not have hours to sit for lunch during the work week, so I would have expected the service to be a little faster. The table next to us actually got up and left after appetizers because they had a large group and the food was taking so long. Another problem was that they were out of one of the options for the Restaurant Week menu. Since there are only three options, I would have thought the waiter would have offered a substitute. All in all, the food was good, the ambiance was nice, but it was too slow for lunch.

Restaurant week is among us once again. So I took advantage of this offer and splurged on a $25 prix fixe lunch. For starters if you plan to drive here give yourself plenty of time.  Traffic in this area is terrible and the parking garages are expensive.  Go online and purchase a parking garage deal, it's worth it!The decor once you walk in is dark, the place is dimly lighted. What's up with the dark lighting these days? Some call it romantic, I call it stupid! Anyway,  we were cordially greeted and shown to our seats. They gave us this delicious complimentary foccacia bread. Nice and hot drizzled with olive oil and a hint of pepper and salt. So here goes, for starters we ordered the corn soup with roasted peppers and the arugula salad that had fennel and ricotta.  The soup was warm and delicious and the salad was fresh and crunchy. For entrees we had the roasted skate fish with fingerling potatoes and the grill pork tenderloin nestled on top of an heirloom bean salad. My son ordered the braided pasta twists with the beef ragu. The entrees were delicious. The fish was perfectly crusted and seasoned. The grill pork tenderloin was perfectly cooked to a medium well. The pasta coupled with that delicious beef ragu was stellar!For dessert we had the tiramisu and prosecco granita,  the granita is sort of like a sorbet. The desserts were sweet, refreshing and satisfying.I must say the service was phenomenally good! Our glasses of water were always filled. One thing to note if you're really hungry this is not the place for you. This is considered fine dining, fine dining in most cases equals smaller portions.

Came here for restaurant week and I have to give this 5 stars. I have been to other restaurants during restaurant week and have gotten sub par service. I received excellent service (water refilled every 5 minutes and inquiries about how my food was with every course). The food was amazing! The beef sirloin was cooked to perfection. I would have to say the trimisu was the best pArt of the meal.

Came here for a business lunch. We didn't have a reservation nor did we come at service hours so the staff put together a bunch of seats in the bar for us. The food was quite good yet pricey. The restaurant borders on a high class chain restaurant spacious enough to serve large groups yet fancy enough to have many sophisticated dish options, none of which were trademarked (tm). I can see how this place may rub some the wrong way, it may appear to be pretentious without merit; but based on the large sampling of dishes I tried (thanks to my company) I would say the food deserves a four star yelp rating. It was flavorful, tasty and truly representative of fine east coast Italian. Service was a bit slow, but I don't like to be rushed anyway. I would suggest the dominos pizza a few block away if you need to stuff your face immediately. Um, just kidding.

At Casa Nonna with my besties Jessie and Judy. Waiter fabulous named after Cary Grant. What a hit. Food fabulous. Steak tender and yummy. Decor a 10. Focaccia crunchy and delicious. Not traditional Italian. More upscale. Pleasantly surprised. Very happy we came.

We went there in a big group actually we were 9 and we decided to go there to have lunch and watch soccer! all of us got our order in about 20 min which was ok, my fiance and I ordered their mushroom pepperoni pizza and the calamari to share,both were really fresh and delicious, the calamari was served with fried sweet paper and potatoes,they also served garlic bread which was tasty. I highly recommend this place.

The ambience is nice and you really feel like you're in an Italian grandma's house. However, the service wasn't all there. The servers didn't check up on us and didn't ask to refill our drinks. The pizza was basic. I could've gotten a better slice at Papa John's. The paninis are nice and filled but rather salty. I wouldn't recommend this place.

Picked this restaurant because we were going to a concert at MSG. I saw reviews and thought "why not." The place is not much to look at from the street but the secret lies inside. The place was quite lovely with several separate dinning areas and a separate bar. Tables were not to close together which is not always the case in NY.  Our waitress was extremely polite and very helpful with the menu. Our appetizers were their meatballs and a mozzarella and peppers medley. The meatballs were very good. The sauce was very good. For dinner my wife had the sea bass with potato wedges on the side. The aoli that came with the potatoes was awesome. I had twisted pasta with a beef pork ragu. It was a really nice sized portion.  The padta was delicious. Also got a side of broccoli rabe. Sometimes it can be too oily but this was perfect.  I had a trio of gelato for dessert. The hazel creme and pistachio were quite good.  Even as the restaurant filled up our service never diminished. The quality of food; the excellent service and the ambience of the place made for an enjoyable evening. Will definitely come back.

Omg the most juicy, tender and delicious meatball I ever tasted! It came in an amazing red sauce with a glob of too good for words ricotta cheese. We started with that and some steak cut potato wedges which were delish. They came with this yummy creamy horseradish sauce. I was told I had to try the chicken Parm so I did - it was glorious. I love how it came with a side of shredded veggies mixed in a cream sauce instead of pasta. This was a fantastic lunch and would come back here in a heart beat.The atmosphere is very nice! Large space, dim lights and tall booths. It feels like you're in your own private dining space. Update: I came back and tried the Bosco pizza with roasted mushrooms, melted onion, ricotta, taleggio, pancetta...HOLY GOD GOOD. I also ate the Battuta Di Pollo which is grilled herb chicken paillard, arugula, perlini mozzarella, cherry tomatoes, VERY fresh and delicious. This place ROCKS. I don't understand how it can get any rating below 3-4.
Very expensive italian place with great food and very small portions.  Staff is rude and not friendly. Total rip off.

I found it to very slow service we went in at 7pm and didn't leave till 9pm. The waiter came over three times and basically left us for his other tables. We ordered drinks that took a few mins to get but based that on the crowd at the bar, we ordered an appetizer that never came, food didn't come till about an hour after we ordered it mean while they put the cutlery down 20mins before the food which gave us the false sense that food would of been served just moments after my fork was placed in front of me. Desert took a while as well because that have to make the plate all nice but could of had a lil more of the rice pudding and less of the chocolate syrup that they had to drench the plate in. Long story short food was ok as long as u don't care about a really long wait. But wait staff really stinks.

Food was just O.K.  Service was very good. Small menu. Appetizer of calamari very very salty. And $9 for iced tea is a bit much. Atmosphere a little dull. Crooked pictures on far wall drove me nuts. $230 for 4 people and no alcohol.

Everything was perfect: ambiance, wait staff, food. Wonderful menu with excellent quality ingredients and some deliciously authentic italian food. I also appreciated the staff: we could enjoy our meal in a non hurried environment. I will come here again for sure.

At first, I wasn't quite sure where I was headed to. There weren't that many restaurants around the place. Located in the fashion district, Casa Nonna is a hidden gem. I found it to be quite spacious inside. We ordered the Calamari Fritti and Polpettine (beef/pork meatballs) to start. This was one of the best calamari appetizers I've tried in a very long time. The lemon-chive aioli dipping sauce was soooo good. For my entree, I went with the Agnolotti Del Plin, which was a ravioli dish with braised veal ragu, wild mushrooms, marsala, and pecorino. I chose this because I love veal and anything with marsala. Perfect! It was a great decision and I had no problem finishing it all. I am definitely coming back; maybe on a Monday night, as all of their bottled wines are half price.

What an amazing experience in NYC!! The meatballs are great!! The best waitress is Taryn!! She is very personable and down to earth and made our 1st dining experience here memorable!!! As this was my 1st time in NYC I recommend all my colleagues to try Casa Nonna!! Remember ask for Taryn!!

Meh. The inside was pretty, but I didn't think the food was very good. For our appetizers, we split the 5 pieces of bruschetta and 4 meatballs. I thought the meatballs were actually really good but the bruschetta was pretty lame. There were three types, and one was so bad, I spit it out. I ordered the "pesto" tuna dish and to our waitresses credit, I was warned that it was not traditional basil pesto but "saltier, like capers." What I got tasted like angel hair pasta sauteed in white vinegar and olives...yikes! I tried my friend's dish which was better, but the bits of  pig ear were so hard, it spoiled what was otherwise a lovely ragu. Drinks were good. Service was just okay, our dinner took almost TWO hours to complete, and the waitress was unable to assist me in finding a spot to plug my phone in. (Which wouldnt've been a big deal at all had she not disappeared with it for an hour)
Great food! The apertizers were a bit "low" on taste, but the main course more than made up for it! Great service and pleasant staff!

Casa Nonna was very nice, great service and food was GREAT! I got the soup for the app, steak for the main and the torta di polenta for dessert. Our sever checked in to see if we were okay or if we needed anything ever so often without being intrusive!  I will be visiting them in the future!

Nice big restaurant! went online looking for good italian restaurants in midtown near work and this place had plenty of good reviews everywhere so I decided to meet my girlfriend there and check it out. They were offering the Restaurant Week menu so I decided to take advantage of that! I dont usually go for the RW menu but I couln't resist the chooices they had...I had the Buffala Mozzarella with the Butternut Squash and Balsamic glaze, very good! my friend chose the Rabbit Confit salad, out of this world! our main courses were very nice too....Braised Brisket with Semolina Gnocci! to die for! and the Ricotta Cavatelli alla Carbonara with Cauliflower and a poached egg on top and pecorino was really great! we were impressed by the really good food and the service was great, very friendly staff. Desserts were great too, Tiramisu with shaved chocolate, divine! and the Torta Polenta with Lemon Cream and Orange Compote was moist and delicious! one of the best meals I've had in a while!...

Amazing focaccia, zuppa di porcini, the food is great. I have to give 3 stars only simply because the check should absolutely not come before the customers finish or barely start the dessert, and then repeatedly pop by to check whether the credit card is ready. It kills the entire experience, which is a shame because the good is very good.

The food was wonderful!!  Great ambiance, but it was empty for a busy night.  Don't let that influence you, I think many are missing a great meal at a great place!  Right around the corner from the New Yorker, where we stayed and we just happened to be walking and passed it.  Made a reservation.  I would say don't pass this up if you're in the neighborhood, you won't be disappointed!

Casa Nonna was surprisingly open and spacious for a Manhattan restaurant. It was a refreshing change of pace. We were seated in a large leather booth far from other dinners. Sitting elbow to elbow with strangers doesn't normally bother me but I have to say I did notice the benefit of privacy. The calamari was fine, nothing particularly noteworthy. The ricotta cavatelli with chunks of lobster however, that was worth writing about. If you are looking for somewhere nice before heading out to the theater, the service was quick and it is only a short walk.

I love this restaurant!! I am definitely coming back!The food was delicious!! I went to dinner here with my boyfriend this weekend and it was great! We got the eggplant bruschetta, the brussels sprouts, the duck ragu buccatini pasta and the branzino. The fish was cooked perfectly. The duck ragu was very filling but delicious! The brussel sprouts were amaazingg! To finish off the meal we got the pistacio and salted caramel gelato. Yum!! Our waitress Taryn was also charming and very personable!! She was able to recommend a great wine pairing. The service and staff were fantastic. Overall it was a wonderful dining experience and i am 100% going back very soon!!

Great service decent foodI was expecting the food to be a little better but the service was definitely great. The chicken parm was pretty good but on the smaller side. Loved how they gave spaghetti squash and zucchini rather than actual pasta. That was a nice surprise.  Stay away from the meatball appetizer it was nothing to rave about.

I've been to Casa Nonna countless times, more for happy hour than anything else.  The food here is pretty good, but not great, and I prefer the food and atmosphere at Mercato around the block a lot more.  Very large restaurant so it never feels intimate.  It's tough to find good places in the area, so I think this gives the managers and even the hostesses a false sense of importance.  Waiters/bartenders are good, other staff are not.

A very nice restaurant; wide open space with plenty of room for large parties. The service was great and the decor was modern and very nice, so an extra star for that but the food was mediocre and nothing to call home about. I thought based on other reviews the food would be better but I wasn't impressed. Maybe I've just been spoiled as I was raised on authentic, tasty Italian food? While it was good, basic Italian, the flavor was bland and nothing we ordered 'blew my mind'. It wouldn't be my first pick in the future, but I guess if I had to eat here again I wouldn't complain?

I rarely recommend restaurant, in fact, I am not even recommending this place any since I don't particularly care but if you think you can find better meatballs, polenta, pulpo, duck pasta anywhere in the city, you're out of your mind. Yes, your grandmother makes everything better, but this place makes everything better than your grandmother.

Really good Italian food  with a good quality bar program.  A fantastic happy hour (a snack comes with each cocktail) with a nice cocktail program and a good selection of beer and wines by the glass.  Great service, even greater when Mercedes is behind the bar.  A go-to in this part of town.

Casa Nonna is definitely as good as it gets for Italian in this price range! First of all, happy hour is great. With every cocktail from the happy hour menu you get a little snack. Win. Second, the gluten free penne is delicious!In addition, the meat sauce is TO DIE for (beef and pork blend I believe)...The charcuterie plate is very very good...the cheese selections are completely overpriced for the serving size, I would pass on that. Wine selections are very good and the blood orange margarita gets you well drunk after 3 of them and tastes great!

We went there on new years for dinner. The food was wonderful and we enjoyed everything we ordered. We had the bruschetta( all 3 varieties) calamari fritti and chicken parmesan. The complimentary flatbread was really good too and crisped just right. There were creamed vegetables sliced finely to replicate spaghetti as a side to the chicken. The service was good/quick, our server was friendly and able to answer any questions we had on the menu.

Had a hugely disappointing and embarrassing experience at Casa Nonna. I was taking some people to lunch for the Christmas holiday, I had raved about this place as the other times I had been there I was very pleased with the food (although it is a bit overpriced).  I had made a 1 pm reservation. Was there on time to be seated and was basically neglected by the people at the front desk. They would say our table was going to open up, and proceeded to sit guest after guest that arrived after us.  When we approached the folks at the desk, we were basically given the same story--"the table is going to be available shortly"---again, more guests were seated. No one got back to us, offered us a drink or made any accommodation. In ffact, we couldn't even get eye contact at that point. It appeared that the person in charge, Robert Martel was hiding from us. At 1:40 my I left with my guests and found a restaurant that would accommodate us. I would never go back to this place.

A very Midtown eatery. Large open space dining area w/ a full bar and then they do  have a private dining room. Perfect for midday business lunch which was I was there.Very clean. Good attentive service. Takes reservations. Had pretty consistent busy atmosphere without being too loud.Typical midtown Italian inspired fare: antipasti, pizzas, paninis, pasta, etc.They do have more full entree, but I went with one of the Italian sandwich options (The Rocker) which hit the spot.Definitely would come back here for a biz lunch.

Friendly service.  Bianco pizza was amazing. Thin crust perfectly done. We then did the four course tasting menu.  We split it between the two of us. It was plenty of food and was awesome from start to finish.

Let's say that this has never been one of my favourite place. The atmosphere is not very well defined. A mix btw an old style italian restaurant and a fancy teather district restaurant. Besides that the service, as you can see in other reviews is not quite excellent. But I was pleasently surprised by the food.The calamari were tasty and not too fried. The pate crostini were deep in taste and loaded. The lamb was very delicate and paired with well steamed vegetables (even if the portion was very small).The price, of course, were exagerated but, this is what you get in most of the restaurants in theater district.

WORST SERVICE EVER--Overpriced food-- rude staff- an entrée of scallops got confused as an appetizer-- they only had three scallops on the plate-- really at the prices they chargeWe went there as a group from work to celebrate a birthday. Being that the staff knew this--you would think that when dessert was ordered they would put a candle in the cake or something-- nope-- in fact dessert came to the table before coffee-- not timed well at all Also -- we really need to ask more than once for a refill on water and bread? A heads up to the waitress -- if you and a co worker are going to talk about our table-- don't point at our table - and make faces.It was a Monday night- you were not busy-- you should have been a bit more attentive and nice.Food- was ok - not amazing ad for what you charge-- portions should have been more generousOverall - not going back nor would I recommend this place

This instantly has become my new favorite Italian restaurant in NYC, and that's saying a lot. It helps that it is in my Hell's Kitchen neighborhood, but the food experience still has me raving 24 hours later. When I visited Florence, a local chef served her Italian marinara sauce that was so perfect that I could just eat it by the spoonful for days. This is the first marinara sauce that I've found that equals it. I came alone, and I was seated promptly at the chef's table facing the kitchen. There were a couple of service issues. I had to wait a while for a server to notice me, and then the kitchen lost my order. So, why five stars? Because of the way that the restaurant and server recovered. Due to the wait for my entree, the chef sent out a complimentary meatball in the marina sauce that was so extraordinary that I will go back just for the meatballs. Later, they served a small dessert. Thank goodness for the recovery because the food deserved every bit of the five stars. The complimentary bread with oil was so crispy and addictive that I had to have two servings, and I don't eat carbs generally. Now, it's a traditional Italian comfort food menu, and not innovative. I had chicken parm that was skillet fried in a light batter, accompanied by mixed vegetables of zuchini and squash strings in a parmesan cheese sauce that was similar to a cheesy spaghetti. The quality of the ingredients, the home made pastas, the charcoal oven grilled pizzas, and the meats made in house all made this restaurant so memorable that I'm still thinking about it, and planning my next visit.

On the pricey side but so worth the money. Upset they took the arancini off if the menu because they were delicious. I had the Fruitta di Mare and it was fantastic. Also the calamari, and my guests had the gnocchi, primavera and the spaghetti with sausage. All were raved over

Soooo delicious!! I really enjoyed my time here! Taking advantage of their restaurant week menu, I tried the cavetelli dish which was out of this world amazing!! It had a light white  wine sauce tossed with chopped onions and peas and everything light enough to make it a perfect summer dish! All pastas here are homemade so another perk.:)Also loves the bar and casual/romantic atmosphere. Great place for a business dinner too if you choose because the place wasn't too loud.I saw that they had pizzas and meat dishes so you choose if you like too.Tiramisu was awesome and I liked the IPA beer I had.Overall great experience. I will so be back!!!

Well lets start with the good part: Food was delish- SO GOOD, and the place is super cute. Downside: the wait staff... after taking drink orders and asking for 1 out of 8 ladies for their Ids, we giggled and said why didn't he card us all and the waiter said b/c he looks for crows feet... he took 3 more drink orders before he realized he offended us all and tried to awkwardly half-ass apologize. We joked about it the rest of the night but as good as the food was, I'm not too interested in returning to be insulted like that again. Ah well.

First things first, the hostess greated me as if we were old friends and made me feel very welcome.  I was given a spacious corner booth in one of the two main dining areas.I then proceeded to wait 10 min for server to even greet me. And the restaurant was NOT busy, it was early on a Saturday night, pre-show.The drink I ordered was sweet and delicious. Made with Lemonciello which I happen to love.As an added surprise they offered me the restaurant week menu on a Saturday night.Bruschetta 3 ways was good, my favorite was the one with pate because it was the only bread slice that was toasted.  Im not sure if that was on purpose or not.Seared scallops had a great color and were cooked to perfection.  The corn and other vegetables that came with it were very tasty but the one downside was I got a bit of sand in a few bites.  Not cleaned properly in my opinion.  I didn't stop eating it and was pleased to not find any more the rest of the meal.All in all, the service picked up

My wife, my son and I had a very good time at Casa Nonna on June 10th.  It has a warm atmosphere and the service is really good.They have an extensive wine list and every bottle is 50% off on Monday.If you go with kids, they have kids menu.I recommend the Filetto D'Agnello (Lamb Tenderloin, Scafata, Rosemary Jus).  The kids chesse macaroni was also delicious.My wife had the Pollete Alla Diavola and here plate was empty at the end :-).Perfect restaurant is you are staying at the New Yorker as this is a 4 block walk.

I'm not usually a difficult or picky eater but I had a pretty bad experience at Casa Nonna, gave them a chance to correct it which they failed to do and as a result wouldn't go back. Here's what happened...First off, it's strange that they have a huge blazing brick pizza oven when you walk in but they don't bring you a pizza menu at dinner. Since it was 90 degrees out and I had to sit about 20 ft from this fiery hot oven I thought we should at least enjoy brick oven pizza! They brought us the pizza menu only because we requested it. The waiter said they want to discourage customers from ordering pizza at dinner because it's mainly for lunch and that's why they didn't bring the pizza menu with the regular menu - weird! The Amelia pizza with sausage and broccoli was pretty good. I will say it was the most interesting pizza on the menu and the others were hum drum (e.g. cheese, pepperoni, mushroom) but had pretentious fancy names. If I was forced to return for some reason I would just have the pizza. I ordered the gnocchi with crispy pig ears and pork ragu as my main (it is technically a primi course). I looooove gnocchi and order it frequently at restaurants. I also make it at home sometimes with frozen gnocchi and sauce from a jar and I enjoy that more than this pretentious poorly executed version. The gnocchi themselves were overcooked and mushy but the sauce was really what ruined it. The crispy pig ear in the sauce was really unpleasant since they were in quite large chunks and are very crunchy and hard, like the consistency of burnt toast. This is an ingredient that should be in small pieces and used sparingly but it's all you taste when in huge chunks and everything else in the dish is mush. Some of the pieces were so hard they were inedible and in addition there were chunks of pork gristle that were also inedible in the pork ragu sauce. Just after I found and spit out a huge piece of pork cartilage in the sauce the manager stopped by to ask how the food was so I showed it to him. He apologized, took the dish away and brought me a menu to order something else. I ordered the risotto which they prepared quickly given the situation. The risotto was just OK. It was bland so I added a bunch of pepper which made it OK but wasn't the yummy perfect dish I think of risotto to be when it's made correctly.My friend that I went with ordered the Frutti di Mare which I tasted and it was just OK as well - it was plain spaghetti with a plain marinara sauce and seafood sprinkled around. I've been to other Italian restaurants in the neighborhood that are much better so I wouldn't go back to Casa Nonna. You can do much better with very little effort.
The best Italian food I ever ate. Generous portions. The four course tasting menu would have fed 2 people. I visit New York several times a year, and I'm definitely coming back.
nice quiet space in fashion district.  good for after work drinks.  Food is nothing incredible but passable Italian-esque.  I would stick to the bar for drinks and snacks.

Man, I just wasn't blown away! And I wanted to be. Everything was tasty, but nothing had me drooling over the table.. I'd definitely still give this place another try though. First thing's first: the bread. They give this delicious, spiced, cheesy bread to really wet that appetite. The bread might have been my favorite thing in all honesty, it was delicious. Onto the apps... I came with a big group, so we orderd a whole bunch of bites for the table: eggplant caponata bruschetta, sweet pea bruschetta, calamari, lasagna verde, and meatballs. The two bruschettas were completly underwhelming. Womp, womp. The calamari was good, and it was a nice surprise to see fried julienne veggies in there as well. The lasagna was alright, nothing to write home about. I'd say the star of the appetizer round was the meatball. Big, juicy, in a pool of delicious tomato sauce with a massive dollop of ricotta and some strips of parmigiano. I could have eaten those things all night!For my entree I went with the seafood tagliolini, with shrimp, calamari, mussels, clams. Unfortunately it seems I got skimped of some seafood. Namely, there were only two mussels and very few pieces of shrimp. The pasta itself was quite tasty, with a light tomato sauce of garlic and herb. I tasted a bite of the gnocci with pork ragu and crispy pork ear-- my runner up for an entree. And let me say I'm glad I didn't order this one. The pork had some layers of fat I had to peel through to get to the meat and while it breaks my heart to say it, the flavor of the sauce wasn't that different from something I might find in a can...While I wasn't blown away by the meal, I did leave full and happy. Service was great, atmosphere is nice. Not a bad spot, seems I just need to try some other things on the menu.
Went for lunch with a important customer.  Great Panini, atmosphere and appearance.  Would like to come back for dinner sometime soon.
Atmosphere was great and food was fantastic! The waiter was quick to modify a dish for me and it was yummy! Would have never found this place without yelp!

Risotto, twisted pasta and lobster ravioli was great. Pita cheese appetizers were amazing! Service sucked (especially for the price we were paying). Our server slid the utensils across the table, told my sister to wait to order because she was number 12... Never going going back because of that.

The decor at Casa Nonna is impeccable. I love that you can partially see the kitchen, but it's still looks very refined and neat. Amazing ambience. The appetizers are great. I order the risotto and found it to watery, but overall it's a great place!

I've been here several times and have always had a good experience.  THE SPACE: Large and expansive, on W 38th St between 8th & 9th Ave.  It was newly built 1-2 years ago, and is a good spot to come if you're tired of being jammed into your seat like at so many other restaurants in Manhattan.  Also they have a large bar area which is a good choice for solo diners or after-work drinks.  THE FOOD: Classic Italian.  They give you free foccacia bread with every entree order, which is great!  I usually go for one of their pizzas, which are delicious.  I've had a couple of the pasta entrees as well and they have been good, though portions can be on the small side for the prices charged.THE SERVICE: Casual and friendly.  I've never had a problem.PRICES: Varies.  Some of their stuff is a good deal, other menu items seem overpriced.  You can never go wrong with a beer and a pizza at the bar for a good, reasonably priced lunch or dinner.OVERALL: Highly recommended, it's definitely one of the better restaurant choices in the Port Authority/Penn Station corridor.
Great food . Terrific ambiance . Service was excellent.  Would definitely return . Loved the grilled octopus appetizer . The risotto dish was out if this world. Yum.

While the vibe of this place is great, my main complaint is with the portion size. I ordered the Tre Formaggi Mezzaluna, which came with 6 small raviolis. I can understand and appreciate serving a smaller meal, but this was hardly a snack (especially when paying $20+ for a pasta dish)

Listen, we are picky about the Italian food we eat in my family. Casa Nonna is better than just about any restaurant we have tried in the city or otherwise. The atmosphere is great and the food more than met expectations. Prices are in line or maybe under  the city norms. If you take children be sure to ask for options for them as they can accomodate outside of the printed menu.

stumbled upon here randomly looking for some snacks to eat while trying to meet some friends who didnt want to go all the way up to hells kitchen.  sat at the bar.  had some solid cocktails.  started with bruschetta/caponata and other assorted apps.  really great food.  simple, but well done, and not crazy pricey.  great service by our bartender, elle.  will definitely be back.  dont come to this neighborhood much, but for pre-theather and pre-msg, this could be my new go to

They have very limited vegetarian selections, one sandwich and one pasta. When I asked for the pasta and requested they don't put broccoli in it, the server started arguing that they won't have anything else to put in. Umm, how about you go ask the chef instead of trying to pretend to be an expert. We kept looking for water refills and no one was around. I'm sure there's better lunch options in this area!

I've been back a couple of more times since my initial review and I think they warrant another star.  Service has definitely improved since my first visit.During my most recent visit, we started off with some apps to share.  The Fritto Misto is Fried Calamari, White Fish, Julienne Vegetables served with a Chive Aioli.  Everything was fried well and was tender.  Items were slightly bland, the seasoning could have been upped a notch.  The bruschetta was another story.  The Baccala & Barlotti Beans version was delicious, such a great balance of flavors with a hint of lemon.  The Sicilian Eggplant Caponata bruschetta was equally wonderful.For the entree I had the Polletto alla Diavola which is a Grilled Cornish Hen prepared with Garlic, Lemon and Hot Pepper; served over a creamy farro. This is an excellent dish.  The hen is seasoned and cooked to perfection with just the right about of heat.  The farro offered a creaminess to round out the dish.  The Grilled Swordfish with roasted peppers, tomato, black olives and capers was also great.  Be sure to get some veggies on the side.  The Brussels Sprouts caramelized with apples and pancetta were to die for and the squash was awesome.As for dessert the Tiramisu was light and fantastic.  The Torta di Cioccolato was Chocolate Olive Oil Mousse, Devil's Food Cake served with Amaretto Crunch Gelato it was totally decadent and divine.Casa Nonna is really a great place in the area for a good meal.

First of all, let me completely confirm what everyone's saying about the complimentary focaccia: it is DELICIOUS. Crispy and buttery exterior with a cheesy interior. So f'n good. Would come back just for that.Came here for lunch with an old coworker. It wasn't too crowded when we started, but it did fill up after 1:30 on a Wednesday. It's a big restaurant with a lot of seating. Bringing a little bit of class to the culinary wasteland that is Midtown West. It's quiet enough to be able to carry on a conversation at normal levels, and the tables are big and spacing is comfortable.For my entree, I had the gnocchi with braised duck. Not the biggest portions, but it was very good. The gnocchi was cooked just right, and the duck/sauce had some great flavor. However, there were some hard/crunchy tasteless bits of something that were overly caramelized or something. Not sure what it was.The Brussels sprouts were also roasted pretty well. They come with caramelized apples, which was a little shocking at first to the palette, but I got used to it and loved it. They were about $8.All in all, I'd say this is a good place for a sit down meal, or for a business meeting. I might have to come back for happy hour, as the other reviewers have suggested!

This place is a diamond in the rough. I never would have thought there could be this good of a restaurant in the Penn Station-Port Authority vicinity, but this place totally exceeded my expectations. First, there are a lot of rave reviews about the bread they serve you when seated, and they are definitely warranted. The bread was really unique - instead of your traditional Italian bread, they serve up a warm flat bread with melted cheese on top.. really good. For antipasti, we ordered the veal meatballs and the arancini. I would highly recommend either, or both! The veal meatballs were tender and smothered in red sauce and a dollop of creamy ricotta and parmesan shavings. Eat everything together and you get a perfect harmonious bite of hot, rich meatballs with cool, light ricotta. If you've never had arancini, I'm a big fan. It is simply a fried ball of risotto with some sort of meat and cheese inside. Just indulge and enjoy. For my main course I had the Gnocchi, with braised duck, wild mushrooms and ricotta. Besides being slightly over-salted, this was seriously tasty. Gnocchi was nice and pillowy, though not the best gnocchi I've had (nothing has compared to the pillows of heaven I had in Italy), but the flavors were all there. Definitely recommend trying this pasta dish. I also mooched and had a bite of my friend's Bianca pizza. White pizza with 4 cheeses, drizzled with truffle oil... I mean, I don't even have to tell you how good it was. I will tell you that the dough was good, thin but not too thin, still had a good bite to it. If I hadn't ordered the gnocchi,  I definitely would have ordered this pizza. After all that food no one had room for dessert, though judging by everything we ate I'm sure they wouldn't disappoint. Topped it all off with a glass of Sangiovese red and overall I would say I had a 5 star Italian meal. Rare for me to rave about Italian restaurants but seriously if you need a go-to in this area, go here! Unlike most good Italian restaurants (which are usually hole in the wall type places), the restaurant is huge so keep it in mind if you need a place that is good for large groups.

This is a challenge for me to write. This place lost a star from me because of the service I received from Luther the bartender.. So let's start out with what worked. What worked was the quality of the wine and food. The other bartender, a young blonde woman with glasses was lovely. The hostesses were polite and welcoming. Since this is about my experience..here goes. It was 6:48 and I had 1/2 a glass of wine remaining. I requested another glass to take advantage of the happy hour. I was told by Luther that there was a NYC state law that prohibited my request. I happen to know that that is an absolute lie since as a bartender myself I have honored the requests of many NYPD officers to serve them a Corona and tequila shot on the side! Which as a professional I do happily. I disputed his answer and he then told me "well it's up to my discretion."  I found that response to be an acknowledgment of his lack of education regarding the law and a commentary on how he thought I deserved to be treated. There was a lovely gentleman whose information I had exchanged with my own for networking purposes who Luther chose to use his discretion and serve at the happy hour price an additional glass of wine after he told me no .I later found out that he was a regular.  I however, was refused. My bill was $18 I tipped $3.00 because I am fair and I am certain that the other bartender was sharing tips with him. She did not deserve to get a poor tip.  I happen to be an African American woman and I do not want to speculate if that was a factor informing his use of  his discretionary options, however it was very uncomfortable and very embarrassing. The gentleman next to me offered to buy me a glass of wine but I refused politely. I simply felt subjected to poor/unfair service and a substandard attitude for an individual committed to being  in the service industry. So there ya go. Yes I will go back, however. I now  know what to expect. Less than I hoped but the food and wine are good and it's near my office. I'll say to my friends going forward...."There is this yummy place with a rude, arrogant and entitled bartender..I hope he's not there". I just noticed Michaela G's review and it was the service that pulled the review down. This is simple feedback and less of a review. feedback is just information. Theirs now to do with what they choose....

They have one of the best complimentary bread. It's like eating a pizza. If you can, ask for refills! Melted cheese inside and on the outside it is buttery. You can taste a little spice to it too. I can just eat this and call it a meal. (*****)There's a few sections of the restaurant (1) the burger spot (2) bar (3) private room (4) two areas for dinning in. The kitchen was very nice too. You see the oven bricked outside so you can see the chief make pizza and the kitchen doesn't have any doors so you can definitely see them cook your food. This is definitely a good place to talk about business. (*****)Service was great. They set up your table before you are seated. The waiters come back and make sure your needs are meet. I don't think the waiter was Italian, but he attempt to speak a few phase.  (****)I had the pepperoni pizza, think of a small Dominos size pizza. It was thin crust. The sauce was just right. Not to thick nor water down with tomato sauce. The pepperoni was the typical round ones. It look like ham too me, but it was very thin too. It went very well with the thin crust. (****)If only they gave me more complimentary bread I would have given them a full 5 star.

I didn't know about this place until I found it listed as a participant for NYC Restaurant Week. I thought it was going to be one of those quaint little restaurants tucked away among the many restaurants in Hell's Kitchen but was pleasantly surprised by the huge entrance, spacious bar and pretty much spacious everything. I loved the decor. And as I try to recall now, it seemed even bigger after having a Dirty Martini with extra olives. But I digress..First the warm bread filled with cheese...so good. My friend and I were pleasantly surprised. At first glance, it looked like just plain bread. Until we took a bite, and wow. While my friend started with a salad, I started with the sausage and polenta, which I finished before my friend could ask me how it was.
